rows.name: help_text
rows.value:
These routines provide designs broken up into individual pieces (usually polygons). The general challenge is to find the total area and the inidividual areas, and then find the fraction of the whole represented by each piece or group of pieces.

These problems can be worked in three ways. One way is to assign a number (e.g. 1) to the area of one piece and have students find all the other areas (no fractions needed for this). Another way is to find what fraction of the total each piece represents. Yet another way is to assign a value (e.g. $10) to the whole thing and ask the value of each piece.

rows.name: topics_text
rows.value: This is an exercise in seeing parts and wholes. It also is great practice in seeing the relative areas of the shapes. This moves students away from just memorizing area formulas and instead develops a feeling for relative sizes and how the figures fit together.

rows.name: advice_text
rows.value:
Encourage your students to see the relationships between the compatibly sized pieces. For example, that the equilateral triangle is half of the corresponding parallelogram and one sixth of the regular hexagon.

There are at least three ways these routines can be done.
* Assign some number (e.g. 1) to the area of one of the pieces, and challenge students to find the corresponding number for all the other pieces and for the whole design. This way can avoid dealing with fractions if you want.
* Challenge your students to find what fraction of the whole each piece represents.
* Assign a value to the whole design â€“ for example, $10 in the Unusual Baker tasks. Then find the value of each individual piece.

rows.name: intro_2_text
rows.value: Each task presents a design broken up into individual regions. Assess what fraction of the whole each region represents.
